awd_titl_txt: Cell-Free Protein-based Bionanomanufacturing of Metal Nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the last two decades, there has been considerable interest in synthesizing new nanomaterials with unusual optical and catalytic properties. This has led to many innovative new applications. The success of this research has created a great deal of enthusiasm for nanomaterials as a solution to the nation's energy, medical, and environmental needs. Unfortunately, very few of these nanomaterials have made it to the marketplace due to challenges with scaling up their manufacturing and finding low-cost and 'green' or environmentally-benign methods to make them at an industrial scale. However, nature does an excellent job of reproducibly making complex metal and semiconductor nanomaterials. This biological inspiration will be used to generate bionanomanufacturing platforms in aqueous solutions without hazardous materials or extreme processing conditions.  This interdisciplinary research will be integrated into the curriculum and provide research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. This project will integrate research with teaching and mentoring, provide unique student internships, and teach them about innovation, intellectual property, and entrepreneurship.

Biological organisms utilize proteins and peptides to produce individual metal nanoparticles at room temperature without organic solvents as a method to deal with metal-ion toxicity in the biological cell. This bio-detoxification process produces uniform and pure spherical nanoparticles. In addition, there is biological programming to the size, shape, and purity of the nanoparticles produced, although the mechanism of this biological programming is not well understood. This award will utilize the bio-inspiration of microbial metal nanoparticle fabrication to build new bionanomanufacturing platforms. This interdisciplinary project will include fundamental biological studies of the mechanisms that microbes utilize to control metal nanoparticle nucleation and growth. These fundamental studies will determine the proteins responsible for control of nucleation and growth. These proteins will be translated to in-vitro manufacturing processes using cell-free techniques for forming the same metal nanoparticles outside of the living cell, but with considerably higher production rates. These cell-free techniques will include protein immobilization, protein stabilization, and cofactor regeneration systems. Finally, these cell-free processes and techniques will be utilized for nanomanufacturing of metal nanoparticle systems of various size, shape, and purity. This protein-based nanomanufacturing will allow for the scale-up of manufacturing of low-cost, but high purity nanomaterials.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Despite the number of remarkable advances in the field of bioengineering and nanomaterials, there still remains a considerable interest in synthesizing and developing new materials that will have significant utility in energy, environment, and medicine. Owing to their high optical, electrical, electrocatalytic, and photocatalytic properties, nanometer-sized materials (i.e. nanoparticles) offer great avenues for both fundamental and applied research. To date, current methods of synthesizing nanoparticles typically require costly chemicals that may be hazardous to the environment. Furthermore, the ability to produce these particles in very high yields and uniform sizes has also been a challenge for many. Hence, there is a need to develop cost-efficient and greener means of synthesizing these nanostructures at an industrial scale. A possible solution is to utilize the natural capabilities offered by nature, specifically by borrowing the machinery of biological organisms in biologically synthesizing nanoscale materials with high reproducibility and great control over their size, shape and purity. More so, this approach offers a way to increase the production of uniformly-sized nanoparticles by simply scaling up the growth of the biological organisms. This grant was focused on (1) fundamentally understanding the mechanisms by which microorganisms utilize proteins to produce size-selected nanoparticles, (2) utilizing this knowledge to produce size-selected nanoparticles in a cell-free system, with the future goal of improving the efficiency and sustainability of this cell-free bioprocessing by utilizing bioelectrocatalytic systems for producing size-selected nanoparticles.

 

Intellectual Merit: This project was an indisciplinary project focused on a new method of bionanomanufacturing utilizing the bacterial enzymes responsible for making size-selected nanoparticles in-vivo. The research involved the discovery of the fundamental bacterial bionanomanufacturing mechanisms and the translation of this bionanomanufacturing mechanism to a cell-free system.  It resulted in 3 peer reviewed publications to date. Broader Impacts: This grant has trained two graduate students, two undergraduate students, and one post-doctoral fellow in multidisciplinary research at the interface between microbiology, enzymology, electrochemistry, and material science.  Over the last few decades, there has been considerable effort in synthesizing new nanomaterials and innovating new applications for nanomaterials due to the interesting optical, photocatalytic, and electrocatalytic properties of materials at the nanoscale. This research and development has been a success and has led to a great deal of enthusiasm for nanomaterials as a solution to our energy, medical, and environmental problems, but very few of these nanomaterials have made it to the marketplace due to issues with scaling up the manufacturing of nanomaterials fabricated from both the “top down” and “bottom up” approaches, as well as finding low cost and green methods to produce these nanomaterials at an industrial scale. However, nature does an excellent job of reproducibly producing nanomaterials with monodispersity. This work used nature as our bio-inspiration to make green and sustainable nanomanufacturing processes. This work will likely also make an impact on the base of knowledge in synthetic biology and cell-free biotechnology, which has traditionally been focused on fuels and pharmaceuticals rather than nanomaterials. 

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2020
Modified by: Shelley D Minteer
